Translation of 郭店楚簡-尊德義(en) into English.

p.seg: Respecting virtue and righteousness,
and discerning the moral principles of the people,
you can be a lord.
To eliminate anger and resentment,
to guard against hate and the will to overcome (others),
it’s the task of the people at the top.
Rewards and punishments
are the foundation of calamity and fortune,
and there have been those who put them in the forefront (of the government).
Feudal positions,
by means of them it is made sure that is like this (=that rewards and punishments are paramount).
Punitive expeditions and invasions,
by means of them you attack […].
Punishments,
by means of them […] actions.
Death penalties,
by means of them you eradicate resentment.
If one does not follow this way,
(one will) not enact (successfully these policies [which the author does not advocate]).
To be humane is to be able to be close (to the people),
to be righteous is to be able to be respected,
to be loyal is to be able to be trusted,
to learn is to be able to be accrued upon,
to teach is to be able to arrange (things) into categories.
Teaching is not (aimed at) changing the way,
but to imitate it.
Learning is not (aimed at) changing moral principles,
but to learn about oneself.
Yu ruled his people (orderly) using the way of man,
Jie threw his people into chaos using the way of man.
Jie did not change Yu’s people
and then threw them into chaos,
nor Tang changed Jie’s people
and then ruled them (orderly).
The sages ruling the people,
(this) is the way of the people.
Yu governing the waters,
(this) is the way of the water.
Zao Fu managing horses,
(this) is the way of the horses.
Hou Ji tending the Earth,
(this) is the way of the Earth.
None does not have its own way,
(but) the way of man is the closest (to good government),
therefore the gentleman
chooses to gives precedence to the way of man.
Examining it (one’s behavior) in its manifestations,
this is how one can know oneself;
knowing oneself,
this is how one can know others;
knowing others,
this is how one can know fate;
one (first) knows fate
and after that one knows the way,
one (first) knows the way
and after that one knows how to act.
From the rites one knows music,
from music one knows grief (passions).
There are those who know themselves
and yet do not know fate,
but there are none who know fate
and do not know themselves.
There are those who know the rites
and do not know music,
(but) there are none who know music
and do not know the rites.
(if one is) good in choosing (talented people),
so that men can follow him,
this is the best.
Because of this,
to lead the people towards the (true) direction,
only with virtue it can be accomplished.
The flowing progress of virtue
is more rapid than the transmission of royal orders by stages and couriers.
If his load (of virtue)
is not heavy (enough),
if he has relationships (with them)
but does not understand them,
he is lost (it will not do).
As for (ways of implementing) virtue,
nothing is greater than rites and music.
Regulate music and harmonize grief (passions),
and the people cannot be perplexed.
Do the opposite,
and they will be reckless.
Punishments do not reach the gentleman,
rites do not reach the common people.
Attack [caos]
and those who were leaving will return,
If one relies on kindness
the wealth of the people will be enough,
if one is untimely
there will be no (concerted) effort (from the people).
If (the ones above) do not love (the ones below),
then (the ones below) will not come close,
if (the ones above) do not […],
then (the ones below) will not cherish (them),
if (the ones above) do not admonish (the ones below),
then (the ones below) will have no awe,
if (the ones above) are not loyal,
then (the ones below) will not be trustful,
if (the ones above) do not employ them,
then (the ones below) will have no protection.
If they blame (them),
then the people will hate (them),
if they are correct
then the people will not be stingy,
if they are respectful
then the people will not be resentful.
Equalization is not enough to make the government balanced,
limitations are not enough to make the people peaceful,
(military) prowess is not enough to suppress the masses,
being broad is not enough to (make them) understand goodness,
being decisive is not enough to (make them) understand order,
killing is not enough to overcome the people.
As for those below serving those above,
they do not follow their decrees,
but follow their actions.
If those above like one thing,
those below will necessarily be even more into it.
Now, because of this,
while virtue can transform (the people)
yet (its) implementation can be shifted (=changed).
Sometimes this implementation
on a small scale is beneficial
but when it shifts to a large scale
it is damaging,
there are cases like this (like material incentives, see 12.12).
Sometimes this implementation
on a small scale is damaging
but when it shifts to a large scale
is beneficial,
there are (also) cases like this (like moral transformation, see 12.13).
If one follows this pattern,
there can subsequently be improvement.
If one follows the constant (way),
then one is secure,
if one examines what is hidden
then there will be no perversion,
if one is not partial
there will be no resentment,
if those above ponder over it,
then […].
People who have their position by inheritance,
are not reachable through education?
Teaching the proper (way of) government
but not the proper (way of being a) man,
(correct) government will not be implemented.
So being thorough (in practicing) these things (=the way of man)
and being deep in them,
can be taught
and (this) should not be doubted.
(but if what) can be taught
is not suitable to lead the people,
the people cannot be at rest.
If one honors humanity,
approaches loyalty,
respects solemnity
and values rites,
one will act
and nothing will be remiss;
if one nourishes the heart-mind with kindness and goodness,
loyalty and trust will increase day by day
without oneself even noticing it.
As for the people,
one can make (=force) them to follow (orders),
but not to recognize them (as being legitimate).
People can be lead,
but not forced.
Jie did not think that his people would necessarily revolt,
but people did revolt.
Receiving unsuitable (orders),
they can be followed,
but not reached (=implemented).
If the ruler of people
leads them in returning to the rites,
the people will eradicate harmful knowledge (=opinions),
(this) is the culmination of laborious thoughts (from the ruler).
To rule a country without using rites,
it is something that cannot be attained by man.
Making happy the people without the rites,
doing this
is (typical) of petty men;
having the people submitting without (implementing) proper social relations,
reaching this (stage)
there is chaos.
Ruling people is not worrying about their livelihood only,
but also not with (their) cravings and desires to harm righteousness.
Bringing to completion the love for the people,
then there is benevolence;
not loving them,
then there is enmity.
The people, if there are five [parts] [=a small amount] (of virtue coming from the ruler)
they will resist (fight),
if there are ten [=a slightly larger amount]
they will struggle,
if there are one hundred [a large amount]
only then will they submit.
If (the ones above) are good,
the people will necessarily be affluent,
(and even if) being affluent
they will not be necessarily in harmony,
if they are in harmony
they will not at peace,
and if they will not be at peace
they will not be joyful.
If (the ones above) are good,
the people will necessarily be numerous,
(and even if) being numerous
they will not be necessarily orderly,
if they will not be orderly
they will not be compliant,
and not being compliant
they will not be peaceful.
Therefore the ruler
chooses to put first the teaching of the way.
If you teach them about the rites,
then the people will be determined and strong.
If you teach them about music,
then the people will be beautifully virtuous, pure and vigorous.
If you teach them about debates and persuasions,
they will be disrespectful and molest, disappointed, chaotic and lawless.
If you teach them about the arts,
they will be wild and quarreling.
If you teach them about practical techniques,
they will be petty and stingy.
If you teach them about words,
they will be boastful and untrustworthy.
If you teach them practical things,
then they will harvest with all their strength to get an advantage.
If you teach them about power and stratagems,
then they will be depraved and befuddled.
Far from the rites there is no approaching humanity.
If you lead them by virtue,
then the people will progress towards goodness.
Therefore the ruler
sometimes regulates it (=virtue),
sometimes nourishes it,
sometimes he lets it come out of (the people’s) inner (feelings),
sometimes he sets it into something external.
He regulates and arrays (the people) according to their categories (of virtuous behavior).
On every occasion, to move the people it is necessary to follow the people’s heart,
the people’s heart has constants,
(one should) search what is permanent in it.
Giving weight to righteousness and gathering its principles,
this is why one talks about these rules.
